The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" includes anti-counterfeiting provisions such as the prohibition against trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 102. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit components, including counterfeit labels affixed to various works, with penalties of fines or up to 5 years imprisonment. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit components, including counterfeit labels like illicit labels used to verify copyrighted works. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distribution of counterfeit labels or documentation intended to deceive copyright owners. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distribution of counterfeit documentation or packaging that deceives copyright owners. This includes counterfeit labels or illicit labels affixed to various types of works. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distribution of counterfeit documentation or packaging that deceives copyright owners, including counterfeit or illicit labels affixed to copyrighted works such as sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, visual art, and copyrighted documentation or packaging. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distribution of counterfeit labels or illicit labels affixed to copyrighted works. The act also allows copyright owners to bring civil actions in court for violations, with the court having the discretion to grant injunctions and order impounding of infringing materials. The court may impound articles involved in a violation and award attorney fees, actual damages, and profits to the injured party. The court calculates actual damages by multiplying the value of counterfeit items by the quantity of those items. The value of a phonorecord, copy, or work of visual art is determined by the retail value of an authorized copy of the copyrighted material. The injured party may choose to receive statutory damages instead of actual damages and profits for each violation of copyright law, ranging from $2,500 to $25,000. The court can triple the damages for subsequent violations within 3 years of a previous judgment. The civil action for a violation must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation. A conforming amendment is made to section 2318 regarding trafficking in counterfeit labels. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under specific sections of Title 17, United States Code, related to electronic transmissions. It also clarifies that the amendments do not apply to certain electronic transmissions of genuine or counterfeit documents under Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not impact fair use under section 107 of Title 17, United States Code, for certain documents described in Title 18, United States Code. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the ``Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act''.

SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946. Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name for a violation. This does not limit what can be considered a willful violation under this section. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement in cases where false contact information is knowingly provided to domain name authorities. This does not limit what can be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as in section 45 of the relevant Act. The 'Trademark Act of 1946' provides for the registration and protection of trademarks used in commerce, in accordance with international conventions. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Sec. 204 amends Section 3559 of title 18, U.S. Code to include a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of felony offenses involving false domain name registration. The maximum imprisonment for such offenses will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines for defendants convicted of felony offenses carried out online using a domain name with false contact information to ensure deterrence. The Sentencing Commission will enhance sentences for felony offenses involving false contact information provided to domain name authorities. The term "domain name" is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205 of the title ensures that free speech and press rights are not affected by domain name registration. It also allows courts discretion in determining damages for intellectual property infringement and terms of imprisonment. In TITLE III, a new court location in Colorado Springs is added. SEC. 302 amends the location of the court in the Northern District of New York by adding "Plattsburgh" after "Malone."
